page.title: 19Wildlife,Bathgate Hills.
page.content: Moles, hedgehogs, shrews: What have they in common? They all eat insects such as spiders, ants, slugs and worms. They all have sharp teeth to eat their prey. Rabbits, hares: Two of the family of grazers, who are able to live in most types of country. Hares tend to live in more open surroundings while rabbits are more adaptable, able to find food and burrowing places almost anywhere. The rabbit needs roughly 0.5kg. of green food each day and about 1/4 of its own body weight. The farmers around this area of Bathgate find that moles and rabbits are a great problem. Foxes:These carnivorous animals are alert and intelligent and most foxes have adapted to living in towns and parks because they often visit these places to find food.
